results.title: Think back: an introduction to safe and efficient patient transfer and object handling
results.creator_credit: Phil Fury, Geoff Crane and Australia. Repatriation Dept.
results.brief_description:
This 1975 film, commissioned by the Australian Repatriation Department, provides instruction on the correct methods of manual handling in order to avoid back injury. The film contains three distinct sections: the first focusing on the principles for lifting heavy objects; the second showing different methods for lifting patients in the hospital; and the third showing methods for manoeuvring heavy loads such as shovelling material and pushing a trolley.

The first section includes animated sections showing the anatomy of the spine and the different types of back injury, including slipped disks, muscle and ligament strain. It then outlines the steps for lifting a heavy load, focusing on a truck driver loading various objects onto the tray of his vehicle.

The second section is directed at hospital staff, as an instructional video for lifting patients correctly. It shows methods of lifting patients up in bed, into a wheelchair and into a bath. Of particular note is the athletic wear (leotards and tracksuits) of the period worn by the nurses and patients in the demonstrations.

The third section shows methods of manual handling in everyday life with correct posture and stability, including shovelling material; pushing a trolley; and lifting a box into the back seat of a car.

A Repatriation Commission Film
Consultant: David Ferguson, Associate Professor in occupational health, the University of Sydney

The colour is faded throughout the film.

Please note: As this is an archival work, the content does not reflect current practice or standards. Professional advice for up-to-date safety practices should be sought from the appropriate contemporary authority.

results.title: Australian Aborigines: living off the land
results.creator_credit: A.P. Elkin and Australian Instructional Films
results.brief_description:
Episode number 9 of Series “Modern social studies”.
Taken during the University of Sydney’s 1952 expedition to Arnhem Land this film shows how local First Nations people live on native animals and plants.

results.title: Jack and the beanstalk
results.brief_description: A short version of the traditional fairy tale in a new medium of silhouette-color, in which black cut-out puppets are manipulated against a colored background. A recent variation on Lotte Reiniger’s established techniques. Narrated by Deryck Guyler.

results.title: In song and dance
results.creator_credit: Don Saunders, Lee Robinson, Joy Cavill, Australian Commonwealth Film Unit and Waratah Film Productions
results.brief_description: The preparations and some scenes of the 1964 Northern Territory Eisteddfod held at Darwin. Local townspeople are joined by cattlemen and First Nations people from far out stations, and get together to produce an eisteddfod unlike any other - with items of all kinds, from classical ballet to First Nations peoples’ music and dance.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Don Saunders, Lee Robinson, Joy Cavill, Australian Commonwealth Film Unit and Waratah Film Productions

results.title: Gulf Country
results.brief_description: The country in Northern Australia bordering on the Gulf of Carpentaria is a flat, dry area in which the rivers and creeks seldom run and isolated water holes keep the wild life and stock alive. At the time when gold was being mined there several townships were flourishing but these are largely abandoned. The Anglican run Mitchell River Mission is located here. At the waterholes may be seen large flocks of ibis and many other birds as well as wild pigs and crocodiles. At times the sky is darkened by flights of flying foxes.

results.title: Going Our Way
results.creator_credit: Chris Gallagher, Victorian Railways and Crawford Productions
results.brief_description: Presents the many employment opportunities in the Victorian Railways. A young boy playing with his toys, including a train, dreams of his future. He becomes a station assistant. Shows how he learns his job and benefits from the V.R.I. library and sporting clubs. Includes executive officers who started at the bottom and worked their way to the top.

results.title: Get out and live
results.creator_credit: Col Lewis and Cameracraft Film Productions
results.brief_description:
This 1972 film, produced for the Main Roads Department, Brisbane, describes the establishment of an emergency control organisation within the department, and shows the training and implementation of an emergency evacuation of 1,500 people from the 14 storey office building.

Produced by Cameracraft Film Productions.

The colour is faded throughout the film and there are jumps in the soundtrack throughout due to missing frames.

Please note: As this is an archival work, the content does not reflect current practice or standards. Professional advice for up-to-date safety practices should be sought from the appropriate contemporary authority.

results.title: Forgotten people
results.creator_credit: Barry Merton and Mathias, Kenyon and Merton Pictures
results.brief_description:
Shows the work of the Aborigines Advancement League (AAL), established in 1957. The film focuses particularly on Pastor Doug Nicholls and AAL President Bill Onus. They visit the settlements of Rumbaland, Robinvale and Dareton, showing the primitive conditions in which First Nations people are forced to live. Government housing is not provided at a sufficient rate. This film stresses the need for more positive action.
Sponsored by the Aborigines Advancement League (Victoria) in the wake of the 1967 Referendum, and featuring two of the League’s founding members in Nicholls and Onus.
